caption:
This photograph captures a close-up view of a large tree trunk, likely that of a giant sequoia or redwood, given the thick, fibrous, reddish-brown bark that is characteristic of these species. The image has a dark, moody tone, emphasizing the rich textures and deep grooves of the tree bark.

The tree fills much of the frame, showing its impressive girth and the complexity of its surface. Stretching across the trunk are several thin, vine-like branches, perhaps from another plant, contrasting with the sturdy, massive presence of the tree. These branches are lighter in color, almost white, adding a visual contrast against the dark bark.

The background is subdued and shadowy, with other trees dimly visible, suggesting a dense forest setting. The top portion of the image offers a glimpse into the forest canopy with hints of sky peeking through the branches, which are silhouetted against the lighter background, enhancing the sense of depth in the foliage.

Overall, the composition focuses on the natural beauty and grandeur of the ancient tree, presenting it as a dominant, enduring force within the forest ecosystem.
title: Old growth western red cedar trees in the Olympic National Timberland the Olympic National Park, Washington. From the Environmental Protection Agency's Project DOCUMERICA collection, "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see Fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. ENTHEOS. June, 1973.
